column4: Hmm how could I get my program to create a new command on ubuntu?
say again?
you need to put it into a directory that the $PATH variable lists. "echo $PATH". i suggest /usr/local/bin.
so physically put the script there?
you also need to have #!/usr/bin/ruby as the first line of your program, and make it executable using chmod +x filename.
yes, of course. the system doesn't look for commands in every conceivable directory in your filesystem... only in /sbin, /bin, /usr/bin, and a couple of others (all listed if you type echo $PATH).
why would you create a .sh file, if your program is a ruby script?
I was reading Clint-'s reply too
i mean, you can give it the file extension you want (including none), but ".sh" is generally used for shell scripts
well, is i read that correctly, Clint- is wrong. you definitely don't need to make a separate script to *start* your program, your program is perfectly capable of starting itself.
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/filename
and then make sure the line #!/usr/bin/ruby is the first line in your program.
now type the command name.
i don't understand what's the problem with it taking input.
you're merely running your Ruby program, no more no less. what did you instead want to achieve?
type something like "Moomake" and my ruby script would start
and it does, provided you called your script's filename "/usr/local/bin/Moomake"
extensions are ignored in Linux
if you put one there, though, you'll have to always put it there.
